Definition: Given a sentence, your responsibility is to classify it into two different classes, which are insult and non-insult. Classify as an insult if the sentence expresses any language that is rude or abusive.

Positive Examples.input: Comment: No wonder Hillary got beat by a circus clown.
Positive Examples.explanation: This comment is insult because it is scornful and disrespectful.

Positive Examples.input: Comment: I guess when you're clueless you stick your head into every hole.
Positive Examples.explanation: This comment is non-insult because it does not disrespect any group.

Negative Examples.input:
Comment: Hillary Clinton was not my girlfriend.

I did not have sexual relations with that woman.
Negative Examples.explanation: This comment might be obscene but not insult.

Negative Examples.explanation: This comment is insult because it is disrespectful.

Comment: I believe Governor Walker has implored those who want to  cut state spending to give him specific proposals, saying what, exactly, should be cut, and how much.  Correct me if I'm wrong, but I don't recall any such proposals being submitted.  "Bloated state government" is a great campaign tag line, but it means nothing in actual governance.  There, specific decisions have to be made and responsibility has to be openly shouldered.  This is what too many legislators--especially Republican legislators--seem incapable of doing.

The House voted an income tax because it saw no other way to close the deficit.  Borrowing from the state savings account is sheer folly; it's like telling somebody to spend their last dime before worrying about poverty.  The state--i.e., the Republicans--stupidly decided to forego the revenues we were getting under ACES.  Now they propose no new revenue, and keep chanting about "bloated state government," as if that's going to absolve them of their stupidity.

Not because the Inuit peoples have hunted the whales for centuries to sustain themselves, but because YOUR past relatives hunted the whales to near extinction for whale oil, and nothing else.  I have been around and spent time with Native Alaskans, and whether it is Moose, Whale or any other animal, I have found them to be very respectful of the animal and the environment.  It is a part of their culture; a culture that has existed for centuries.  The Native Alaskans haven't raped and pillaged the planet, WE are the ones who have done so, with our desire for modern conveniences.  They are not hunting for sport, they are hunting to sustain life.  To attack them is show your ignorance and hate.

Comment: I, too, have a dash-cam installed, front AND rear-facing.  It's already paid for itself from claims that something was my fault, when it wasn't. Comment: Now that's an idiotic & ignorant remark if I've ever read one! "Just stop smoking. I didn't need the patch or anything". Simply because the "cold turkey" approach worked for you doesn't mean that it'll work for everyone! Your sweeping "analysis" doesn't account for a myriad other critical considerations: how long the individual has smoked, the number of cigarettes that person has typically consumed in a given day over that period, the actual strength/nicotine level of the favoured cigarette brand, the rate at which each cigarette is consumed, full or partial consumption, the conditions/settings where the smoking typically takes place (socially or universally, post-meals, with meals, with alcohol, with coffee,  post-sexual activity, etc.), filtered vs plain cigarettes, the reason the individual started smoking & continues to do so (peer pressure, social rebellion, stress relief) & the subjective length & severity of withdrawl symptoms.

In other words, your claims are baseless & facile!

Comment: That's ridiculous. I'm in Tier 4,  having brought a private 403b retirement into State service five years ago. Tier 4's 401K is growing much faster than my retirement ever did at my last employer. What's more, my transferred funds are growing at nearly twice what they were under my last employer's program.

Yeah, compared to Tier 1 which was a defined compensation plan that made State of Alaska retirees into millionnaires, Tier 4 is low-rent, but it is on par with 401Ks around the nation and well-invested. Plus, you don't pay the stupid Social Security taxes which are just spent by the government so there's a real possibility that when you retire, the funds won't be available. Instead, your contributions are wisely invested with a growth rate on the principle of about 6% annually -- exactly what every major employer in the country offers (except in private companies, you still have to pay the Social Security taxes)

Comment: Quote from the article:  Among the misconceptions about Pidgin, said Darrell H.Y. Lum, a panel speaker and the co-founder of Bamboo Ridge Press, is that it is “broken English” or a “language of the stupid.”  I've lived in Hawaii for 60 years, grew up in Hilo, learned pidgin for casual conversation among local friends, am part-Hawaiian, dropped my Southern drawl, and became an English teacher and librarian.  In all those years, I have never heard anyone describe pidgin as broken or for the stupid.  I've known people who were fascinated and intrigued by it but never considered it broken or the people who spoke it stupid.  Using pidgin to communicate in certain circumstances and contexts is one thing.  Yes, there IS a time and place for it.  Teaching students to speak it in public schools?  When hell freezes over and pigs fly.  Fix the current problems with public schools before creating another one.

Comment: Our LCBO is just a long standing remnant of prohibition.  Basically, alcohol sales are banned in the Province of Ontario.  A person or company cannot sell alcohol to another person, period.   

There are two exceptions, beer sales through a privately owned "brewer's co-operative" and sales by the province through the Liquor Control Board.  

So, if you want to sell alcohol in Ontario, what you do is sell your alcohol to the LCBO, at whatever price they determine it is worth (no competition, so you get what they give you) and the LCBO resells it at whatever markup they please (usually 200 to 300%).  

What we have now is a public service union that wants to get in on this cash bonanza with the usual full time, high salary "jobs for life".  The only grounds for all of this, is that the govt is "protecting us" from the evils of alcohol, by selling it to us at hugely inflated prices, and preventing anyone else from doing the same.  

That is it.  It's a morality play.  Stupidity.

Comment: No doubt WWI was a foolish war that ended so badly WWII was bound to follow; the treaty was poorly done.

But there is a certain truth to the assertion that it made Canada a nation.  I agree with Ms Wente in that it is difficult to find nation building stories, since unlike most countries, Canada slowly evolved to nationhood.  We have no revolution to glorify, and we have never had conflict on our own soil except as a colony.  Illustrious tales are few, we slogged our way into nationhood, and the first seeds were sown not by us but by Britain in 1867.  WWI proved we could stand on our own.

As an aside, I am saddened by Wilson-Raybould 's remark that it is “hard to celebrate 150 years of colonialism.”  Aboriginals got a raw deal, true enough, but even though our history has its share of lamentable events, we have also done much to be proud of.  I can't think of a country I would rather live in.  If Mr Wilson-Raybould is ashamed of his country he has no business in cabinet.

Comment: The article is absolute garbage and falls into the category of fake news.  Perhaps the Globe and Mail took the piece for free as a favour for someone's church  "They forget the underlying assumptions, namely that trade consists of the balanced exchange of final goods under freely floating exchange rates, with no capital mobility between countries and full employment."  If there is no capital mobility, there is little trade.  Perhaps they are bartering.  Regardless, there is no 'balance exchange of final goods" per economic theory. Comment: Reguly is right that self-driving cars will not eliminate parking. People accustomed to personal vehicles won't always want the self-driving car to go away when they reach their destination. They use the car as a rolling storage locker. 
When many people are going to generally the same area, mass transit such as trains and buses is the obvious solution. Experience shows that we can build transit, but many people will invent reasons why they simply must go in their own car. Politicians ignore the refuseniks at their peril. 
The benefits of self-driving cars have probably been oversold. They are not a panacea, but in some cases they might be a workable compromise for a stubbornly car-dependent population.

Comment: I have said before, "The only thing worse than working is being unemployed."

While tongue in cheek it also has a level of truth to it.  Most of us work but fear of being unemployed - with the social pariah hood that accompanies it - inhibits many of us from exploring other ways of participating and creating meaning in life.  Of course, not having enough money to survive is also a fear, but as the article discusses there just may not be enough work to go around in the future.  

So then what?

That is what we have to determine on a societal and personal level.  Societally it is important that people are engaged in meaningful pursuits - whether they have over economic value or not - to avoid alienation, and the host of attendant ills that accompany it.  Personally, most if not all of us want to be doing something we consider meaningful, and still have enough economic means to meet our needs.  Having the confidence, motivation, opportunity and means is essential.  But how do we do it?

Comment: I read the part about the need to stop celebrating retirement and the comments that followed in this thread,  and have to say I have very mixed feelings on this subject. Some people have jobs or businesses (professions) that they love, and want to continue, or else want to start new careers.  That's great. Then there are others who want to retire in their late 50s or early 60s, if their financial situations allow them to do so, in order to play golf or otherwise pursue lives of leisure for the rest of their days. That's ok, too, because only a minority of people are in the latter category anyway. If too many people were to retire and pursue lives of leisure, society would certainly be in trouble. On the other hand, if most people  wanted to continue working into old age, that would present a big problem, because many younger workers would have to wait on the sidelines for good-paying jobs to come their way and thus create a lot of resentment on their part. No easy answers to this!

Comment: The phrase ". . . never seen before" in relation to climate change, to imply that what is happening is something that has never occurred before in history, is rather elitist and 'species-centric.' Just because YOU haven't seen it, doesn't mean that it hasn't happened already.

     'Climate change' is no hoax;  Implying that it's something oh-so-new and 'never seen before' IS.

Comment: It should not be so difficult to understand that one ski area's "earlier than usual" opening  is not an indication of a temperature (or TEMPERATURE) trend. Neither is a late snowfall in Denver. Neither is a one month drop in SSTs. Neither is a ~17 month drop in sea level. And it should not be so difficult to understand that what actually is an indication of a temperature trend is an obvious change in direction of data collected from thousands of thermometers over many years.

Returning to the subject of the original piece, meteorologist Ken Kunkel analyzed 121 years of data from 700 weather stations to arrive at his findings of a trend for first freeze dates. He understood that it required a bit more (and a bit more relevant) data than A Basin's opening date in 2017 and 4 weeks of decreasing SSTs to arrive at his conclusion. If you feel so compelled to dispute that conclusion, the journals await your own analysis.

Comment: Good old days it was. Can imagine when the British lived and enjoying the exotics flavors of the Orient. Dining on Chinese food in Hong Kong and then visiting an opium parlor. Settling in Bangkok, Manila, Kuala Lumpur, and Singapore casually strolling through the evening's exotic smells after dining on fish, poultry, shrimp, beef, all prepared with local spices and sauces they've never witnessed before. Silk shirts and tailored suits to be ordered at bargain prices and worn, concubines to be loved, fighting cocks to bet on, languages to be learned to communicate with the house maids, drivers, gardeners, laundry people who were paid pennies along with food and boarding allowances. Those days are almost gone as westernization creeps in as progress. Sadness of remembrances.

Comment: No problem at all. The United States began when former separate colonies united in opposition to British rule. Absent the crown's authority, those separate colonies considered themselves independent states. They were persuaded to join a union of such independent states- the United States of America- by allowing them to retain a great deal of control over their own government, laws and social order. That included the existence of slavery.

Getting rid of slavery had to happen, but you can see how doing so would draw huge resistance in those former colonies where it was deeply ingrained in the economy and culture. T slave states had a justifiable political grievance- the principle under which the union was first formed was being usurped. Their way of life was about to be overthrown, and obviously that wasn't the reason they signed on to the Constitution.

Comment: High tariffs prompted the Nullification Crisis in 1831-33, when, after South Carolina demanded the right to nullify federal laws or secede in protest, President Andrew Jackson threatened force. No state joined the movement, and South Carolina backed down. Tariffs were not an issue in 1860, and Southern states said nothing about them. Why would they? Southerners had written the tariff of 1857, under which the nation was functioning. Its rates were lower than at any point since 1816.

"Declaration of the Immediate Causes" ... Confederate states did claim the right to secede, but no state claimed to be seceding for that right. In fact, Confederates opposed states' rights - that is, the right of Northern states to NOT SUPPORT SLAVERY " and protested that Northern states had failed to "fulfill their constitutional obligations" by interfering with the return of fugitive slaves to bondage. Slavery, not states' rights, birthed the Civil War.

Comment: With all due respect it sounds I think you have this backwards.  I'm assuming you don't have much knowledge or experience in green build so as a LEED GA and Architect-in-Training let me try and share my knowledg.  Please don't hesitate to let me know if you have any questions.

Builders don't profit off of long-term ROI, they would likely lose money or possibly break even. Most builders sell the property off either to individuals or to another owner who rents it out thus  the theory, mostly of the left, is that builders don't care about "life-cycle cost" they only care about up front cost which would mean things like green roofs and solar panels don't get built.  I think that shows a nieve lack of understanding as any competent buyer would study the O&M (Operations and Maintenance) costs and take those life-cycle costs into account which would of course influence their offer price to purchase the property so that builders, in fact, do have an incentive to do things like green roofs.

Comment: The old ancient sewage system plan, from Dan.

Indian Chief 'Two Eagles' was asked by a white government official; "You have observed the white man for 90 years. You've seen his wars and his technological advances. You've seen his progress, and the damage he's done." 

The Chief nodded in agreement. 

The official continued; "Considering all these events, in your opinion, where did the white man go wrong?" 

The Chief stared at the government official for over a minute and then calmly replied.. "When white man find land, Indians running it, no taxes, no debt, plenty buffalo, plenty beaver, clean water. Women did all the work, Medicine Man free. Indian man spend all day hunting and fishing; all night having sex." 

Then the chief leaned back and smiled; "Only white man dumb enough to think he could improve system like that."

Comment: Many of us who live on the lower Cook Inlet remember this somewhat differently. We observed humpback whales staying in our waters later than anyone could ever remember seeing; through September, October, into November, and many until the first of the year. There were extraordinary numbers of murres as well, staying well past the traditional time when this species would migrate from the region.

These creatures didn't linger because there was a lack of food, on the contrary, there was a tremendous amount of food, and temperatures were unseasonably warm. Those of us who took to the water (from Koyuktolic Bay to the head of Kachemak) saw tremendous balls of bait  fish.

These bait fish often leave our waters as quickly as they arrive. In less than a week's time, early November, a great preponderance of these balls of bait left the area. The murres had stayed too long. A heavy 80 knot wind hit the area and caught the birds unawares. Blowing them inland all the way to Lake Illiamna.

Comment: Natural cycles and oscillations have indeed been drivers of historic climate change, and will continue to act as such in the future. But nothing happens without cause. Natural, cyclic influences on climate are the result of changes in the Earth's orbit, variations in solar irradiance/insolation, and ocean circulation changes. We know the state of each of these factors. They are carefully monitored. Most have known periodicities. None of these cycles/oscillations has been responsible for modern warming.

In the meantime, we know that the anthropogenically-sourced 40% increase in the Earth's most influential "greenhouse" gas (CO₂) has indeed been responsible for warming.

BTW, the LIA ended closer to 200 years ago. It was not a globally synchronous example of climate change, mostly affecting the northern hemisphere. And no, global temperature just prior to the LIA was not as high as it is currently. Globally, we are now likely warmer than the last 120,000 years.

https://xkcd.com/1732/

Comment: Again, I don't think you'll get any result but glazed eyes talking about AMOCs and SAMOCs. And it's looking at this little region. We're on this large globe, and that globe's overall physical picture is what actually matters, especially if you're seeking clarity from a top-down level of understanding. My only point was, there's very little space and time for arcane details like that when the greater message is much more urgent for the world. 

Regardless of what the ocean circulation patterns do, it's the heat gain and the entropy that drive the system and inform the main concerns, having to do with livable climate and tipping points for out-of-control runaway change. It's no big deal, unless you liked the ocean where it was, and all that biodiversity, which cannot always move fast enough in shifting temperature zones to adapt and survive. One or two bad enough harvests, though, make life hard, as can droughts, floods, and heat waves.

Comment: Politicians and grifters like Jamie Oliver have seized on the "nudge" idea to justify taxes and other coercive policy. But the original concept was never about that.

A "nudge" means tweaking the landscape of choices so that the default or easiest option produces a desirable outcome. But it doesn't forbid someone from making a different choice if they wish.

A nudge would be to put healthy drinks in a more prominent position in the store aisle. Consumers can still access the full-sugar drinks, but they're not the most obvious choice.

On the other hand, the tax is more of a "shove". You're forced to pay the tax, or give up the drink. You cannot skip paying the tax and still get the drink.

Comment: There is a "gorilla in the room," in this situation.  Fiat-Chrysler now faces it with its eco-diesels.  I can not be sure (ie cannot prove it) but have learned of a highly probable alternate explanation which will emerge if FCC has to fight it.
Emission performance is a combination of defined outputs (ie what is measured, by what means and in what connection with the source when it is operating under what circumstances and parameters...)  This situation is less science than attitude on the part of scores of people who make the standards, carry out the testing and do any of the thousand other things essential to such an activity.
My "understanding," is that VW let the authorities follow a course of enforcement practice that was not likely to yield relevant results in the circumstances.  It may not have been the duty of the regulated to correct the errors and omissions of the regulator....  making this a USA heavy-hand / market leverage issue more than anything.  Bureaucratic!!!

Comment: When the comments board was alive with opinions on electoral reform, the idea that this would never happen was front and centre. Yes it was a promise, but suddenly people were behaving as if they had never seen an election promise broken, for any number of reasons. People seemed to have forgotten that this was a third place party, and like parties before it will promise anything, sometimes on the basis that they know they are not going to win, but simply to improve their standing. There are two main parties the Liberals and the Conservatives, who take turns sharing power, and the Liberals turn comes up more often then the Conservatives. The Conservatives wanted the status quo, and the Liberals weren't prepared to ram through a change that benefited them, since they win more often then they lose under the current system. As for fairness, politics is about winning and gaining power, the two main parties would never stack the deck against themselves at the interest of fairness.

Comment: Your comment raises an interesting question. Reading Thomas Aquinas back into Jesus' time, I'm sure you will say there must have been a 'transubstantiation' at the last supper. That did not seem to occur to Jesus.

Jesus never thought in terms of Aristotle's philosophy. He was thinking more in terms of Jewish practices of a covenant, and Passover remembrance.
 Whether he was 'present' in two different forms that Thursday night – in his actual human form, and distributing his 'sacramental' presence, likely never occurred to him. Did He 'transubstantiate' himself? Certainly he had not died as yet, so that his death could be 'remembered'. He was giving them a model of something to do in the future.

And when they finished the meal, they just got up and left. No 'tabernacles' or anything. I expect Jesus is rather amazed at our philosophical gymnastics.

I hope they try a service animal again, for the boys independence, health, and safety.

Comment: I am a regular driver on Willamette. For drivers, there are some obvious advantages to the new design. The left hand turn lane is helpful. Around 4-6pm, you have to wait for a traffic light to clear the way, but that's not a very long wait. The improvements for access to Woodfield Station are the biggest improvements for me. Well done!

The damage for drivers is also pretty obvious. Traffic is backed up as far as you can see at rush hour. Access roads are also backed up. 29th was backed up most of the way to Amazon Parkway on a recent afternoon. Cars were turning off to avoid the back-up, which is what I did. Twice now, I have forgotten about the weekday jam, and I have turned back when I saw it. I am planning to avoid Willamette between 4 and 6 on weekdays, at least. 

I believe that the "study" will show whatever the planners want it to show. The deed is done. I predict less traffic on Willamette, which is what the planners wanted. I hope that the changes turn out to be safe.

Comment: The modernization of the law is to limit rights of the accused to present a full defense. This is shocking and should be resisted at every level by Canadians. One aspect of modernization that clearly requires change is to issue publication bans on both the naming of the accused and complainant in sexual assault trials. What is happening  on social media is appalling to the accused. Remember that they are presumed innocent and unless convicted remain innocent. So why is dragging their names through the courts any less traumatic than it would be for the complainant? The argument that sexual assault has such a societal impact on naming the complainant applies equally to the accused. It is time to impose bans on the publication of both names until the resolution of the trial. At that point, and only at that point, does the public have any right to know. Anything else is blatantly sexist.

Comment: Hello MilesD,

My impression is that comments can be "disappeared" through various mechanisms, none of them to do with "a glitch".

1. The laypersons who do the initial reviews trash them as badly uncivil posts, when they are not, and it does not see the light of day on the baord.
2. The laypersons let it get posted, but it gets flagged by others as offensive (when it is not, it simply grates on their sociopolitical preferences), and in some silly fashion gets deleted when it ought not get deleted.
3. I suspect the columnists and journalists themselves have access, should they want it, to fast-track intervention with those in charge of board moderation.

I am not suggesting it is a Globe and Mail editor who is behind what is happening.

But whoever is behind it, come on, surely you have noticed that in some subject areas, lots of posts get "disappeared" for reasons that have nothing to do with "civility" of written content (examples, anything related to Islam or indigenous natives).

Comment: Read all versions of the bill about 3 times.

"2.  No lease can be longer than 65 years."  Absolutely false.  171-36(b) (1) specifically empowers the Board to modify the restrictions in 171-36(a), including 171-36(a)(1) which limits leases to 65 years.  Currently, 171-36(b) specifically allows for extensions or modifications of the lease period, as long as it does “not exceed sixty-five years.” HB1469 CD1 proposes to eliminate that cap, as long as the board approves a development agreement. This empowers the board to give out leases FOREVER, for almost ANY lands, not just for resorts, that supposedly need more than 65 years. This would specifically allow the Board to extend the Mauna Kea lease for another 50, 60, 100 years, binding the hands of Native Hawaiians and the public for multiple generations. Do you know how much can change in that time?

the CD1 would also allow for options for renewal, currently prohibited, which could result in leases longer than 65 years.

Comment: Basket,  I disagree with your interpretation of the deferral. I think the deferral results from the difference in the corporate tax paid annually by the corporation and what is paid when the capital is removed from the corporation.  Once the capital is removed from the corporation, it is taxed at the nominal rate. The benefit is that money left in the corporation can be invested and earn additional returns (thus paying additional taxes - capital gains).  Taxes are paid in full, there is just a delay between when the revenue is earned by the corporation  and when the individual pays the income tax on them, similar to an individual RRSP.

Comment: The new discoveries (naledi being only 250,000 yrs old etc.) are extremely interesting, but prof.Berger's anthropo-centric interpretations (human relative, deliberate burial, distance runner, tool making) are outdated (pre-darwinian): naledi was most likely a fossil bonono-like ape, but with more humanlike feet (full plantigrady) & smaller front teeth. The fossil was found in mud-stone (which fossilizes in +-stagnant water, e.g. wetland & forest swamp). Naledi's curved hand-bones show frequent vertical tree-climbing. The flat feet (very unlike ostrich & kangaroo) suggest frequent wading, like bonobos do when wading bipedally for shallow aquatic herbaceous vegetation (AHV), google "bonobo wading". The small anterior dentition suggest abrasive or calorie-poor foods (AHV), google "Pan naledi 2017 Verhaegen".

Comment: I am a Leaf driver for 2.5 years. Bought second hand no subsidy on purchase side. fuel costs about 1.5cents per km. Zero maintenance bills so far except flat tire and dead FOB. Battery at 85% and 85,000 kms driven so far. 
Is it a single primary car for us? No - not there yet due to size and range.
Is it an economical, fun, quiet, efficient ride ? Yes.
Will the next generation (now on the market) address most of the concerns I have with range? Yes
Will my next (and next) car be electric? You betcha!
I see the % of cars that are pure EV or PHEV going to 5% new sales in 5 years. This is a pretty big number and I see no reason why this won't happen based on my driving experiences.  After that, it will be mainstream option and another important segment of the auto industy - like trucks, or SUVs, or other similar categories. It will be fully competitive with ICE technology with appropriate pluses and minuses.

Comment: Grand theory, but as with so many collective undertakings, there is insufficient public interest to adequately discharge the obligation implied by that "prerogative of all".  

People tend to mind their own business, and the path of least resistance involves abandoning criminal justice to the a criminal justice environment where it is quite evidently about the criminals, the lawyers, the judges, the expert witnesses and every other employee or servant of the court down to the security guard.

Even bona fide victims, like newzea7, have learned to expect little from the criminal justice system as it is presently oriented, and they soon give up any hope of ever seeing justice.  The cops know that some smart-ass hair-splitter in a suit is going to decimate any case that isn't black-and-white, and they send that message along to victims, whether they've been stolen from or sexually assaulted.

Retuning the justice system to serve some independent interest would be a good start.

Comment: Anyone who reads them should conclude that Fossil Fuel companies have been aware of the reality of Global Warming and the CO2 link, for decades. Most Canadians understand that Climate Change is real because we have seen it for ourselves. My mother in law used to go skating for months every year on Elk Lake, Rithet's bog and Panama flats back in the 1930s. Now those rarely freeze over and not long enough for safe skating. The "Ice Ramming" MV Manhattan had to give up on the McClure Parry passage on both attempts in 1968 and 1969, turning south to narrow, shallow passages too dangerous for routine traffic by supertankers, and well within Canadian Territorial boundaries. Now McClure Parry melts open safe for non ice strengthened ships every year, like clock work. The Pole will be ice free for 90 days every year within decades, according to the Chief Navigator / Oceanographer of the USA Navy. The 20 meter pressure ridges that stopped the Manhattan are long gone.

For the rest of the NT the soul, when mentioned at all, is simply the life principle and dies with the death of the body, which is why Paul in 1 Cor 15 has to speak of the risen body as a penumatic body, given as a new creation. As I remember my scholastic philosophy, experience, insight etc. were faculties of the soul, which was adopted because philosophically it assured each person was already immortal and thus had to take care of living with faith and grace. Comment: That's common sense they should be talking with the US to mitigate trade problems, so that's good. Comment: JC,

That is not a very good analogy. For one, you don't actually possess the right to have a lawful society, thought you do benefit from one in Canada. Second, a common test placed on ones freedom to act in society without hindrance is the harm principle. Using this test, one can can clearly establish that those who exceed the speed limit are more likely to cause accidents that could physically and demonstrably harm others. Therefore, they are prohibited from doing so by the law. Ones unwillingness to use another individuals desired pronoun or support their chosen way of life does not sufficiently harm the other in a demonstrable fashion. Hurt feelings is not enough to meet the harm principle test or we'd be in a world of problems as everyone would be before the court for hurting others feelings one way or another. One should have the right to their chosen gender identity, no question, but that right need not require others to do anything but not impede their choice.

Comment: Veterans groups keep telling the government what veterans need and what the VA needs. The VA needs less red tape to hire new employees. Government hiring freezes and attempts to funnel money from properly staffing VA's to expensive and less useful civilian care have left most VA's critically understaffed. I understand that politicians want to look like they care about vets while funneling vets to private civilian care. But it doesn't work for us. 
Civilian providers won't take our low government pay for services, even if it's more expensive than VA care. And the care civilians provide is substandard for veterans health needs. Military members are exposed to unique toxins and environments like burning oils fields and depleted uranium and such, and unique stressors like the conditions of battle and military life. We need veteran specific care and the peer support of contact with other veterans. 
Fix hiring and properly staff our VA. Don't let them privatize our care to please lobbyists.

If, however, we also take into consideration the achievements of social sciences – such as those of psychology and sociology – there is no room left for religion, which becomes a relic of the prehistory of humans.  In psychology, for example, we learn that our dreams are the product of the work of our own brain – and not messages from the… supernatural world.  And the father of sociology, Auguste Comte, teaches us that the “Great Being” is not some god… living in Paradise, but it is our own society – which humanizes us, loves us, hates us and… dominates us. Thank you. A. C.

Comment: Thank you Charles for providing some rational thoughts to the controversy of Alaska's predator control programs.  The 1997 independent evaluation of our predator control program by a panel of distinguished scientists of the National Academy of Science found numerous deficiencies. Ten years later the panel chairman again reviewed the status of Alaska's predator control programs and he found no evidence of improvement, rather, he concluded: " Indeed, recent predator control efforts have not been designed to test whether predators are actually controlling prey populations.  Rather, control efforts have been initiated under the assumption (or conviction) that predators are the cause and the solution to the “problem” is intensive predator control.”  The old notion that less predators = more moose is alive and well at ADF&G and the BOG even though Aldo Leopold, the "father of wildlife management," published has classic essay, Thinking Like A Mountain, nearly 70 years ago.

Comment: There are several reasons man-made climate change is not universally accepted. One is that it is a relatively new science and it requires more study than Trump, or most people really, would be willing to do. It is a very complex field with more variables than even computers can sort out. And since there is no such thing as a climate change-ologist people from many fields of study need to try to cooperate to get a clear picture of reality. Cooperation between the sciences rarely works out well since each branch thinks they have the Holy Grail of knowledge.
Anyone who seriously believes man has not soiled the nest of planet earth for well over a century ignores historical fact and reality. How this mass pollution will play out for us two legs is up for debate but likely forces we don't even recognize will make most predictions irrelevant. We think our science knows and sees all but we only just rediscovered things like the Ice Ages and the Bering Land Bridge(s) recently. Stay tuned in...

Comment: My 2012 Nissan leaf electric car is equipped with "vehicle sound for pedestrians".   It's a backup chime similar to the door-ajar sound on other sedans and only a slight whistle as you accelerate off the line. It only has to be loud enough to be audiable from about 10ft. you barely even hear it in the car.  I'd prefer if it wasn't there but it's still very quiet.  Electric cars in general are far far quieter than gas engines, hence the requirement for noise makers.  You never really notice how loud a gas engine is until drive a vehicle that doesn't need one.  The roads would be much quieter if everyone drove electric. Test drive one! I love sports cars but the instant torque and a vibration-free electric motor makes a pretty nice ride.

Comment: "The employer contribution has shot up in the past decade to the point that it is closing in on 20 percent of payroll."

So let's compare that to the typical private sector benefits for a major employer.  Commonly, the private sector involves Social Security plus a 401(k) plan with some employer-match.  A common employer-match is 3-4% (let's say 4% to be generous).  The employer's contribution is 6.2% for SS and around 4% for 401(k) for a total of around 10%.  The employee pays 6.2% for SS and commonly around 8-10% to their 401(k), for a total of around 15%.

Per the article, PERA participants pay just 8%, while the employer nearly 20%.

Summary:
Private: Employers contribute 10%; the employee 15%
PERA: Employers contribute 20%, the employee 8%

Not much question who's getting the far more generous retirement deal.  

(And it actually may be worse that that, if "20% of payroll" means 20% of the total payroll budget. That would be at least 25% of salary.)

Comment: Joan Conrow, You say you support GMOs, but not the GMO producers.  That's quite a fine distinction.  GMO producers have engaged in harmful practices.  Have you ever criticized any of those practices?  You say you opposed HB 790 because it was poorly written.  There was some testimony opposing HB 790, but the opposition was based on substance, and I couldn't find any testimony that said the bill was poorly written.  You or anyone else can propose an alternate method for determining if pesticide use on Hawaii seed crops is harming people.  However, HB 790, or other similar measures introduced in the legislature, was the only one that could accomplish that.  In public hearings, no testimony proposed any alternative. For example, when you write that Wikileaks exposed direct coordination with the Clinton campaign and the media, what you really are talking about is a couple of independent incidents with a couple of different reporters (not an overarching conspiracy among the majority of the hundreds of journalists covering the campaign). While partisan media definitely has pushed people apart, the "traditional" media has had a much lesser role in that. I also don't think the evidence supports the assertion that Trump's words have been taken out of context (by traditional media, not partisan media), or that the messengers (not the actual actors themselves) have stoked fears and racism. Significant issues were not addressed in this past campaign, such as environmental destruction, because the public didn't demand it. Media generally gives its audiences what they demand.

Comment: What's a "plutocrat-owned" newspaper?  As opposed to ?
But - I digress: Home-schooling in AK was a necessary adjunct to our pre-oil, pre-electronic, significantly rural State condition in a time of very limited State wealth & communication capacity. It was mostly for rural parents & kids without local choices, because they lived in villages too small for high schools; or perhaps even for public elementary schools; or in homestead-type rural isolation.  In some cases it was for rural parents who didn't want their children to attend the local school that had been established & was run by religious or cult groups. And yes,I've seen excellent academic & socialization results from home schooling - and some very troubling academic and socialization results emanating from public education. BUT - as with the condition of the 2 girls in the recent ADN story- without monitoring or review- we have opened the door for monster- or merely inept- "parents" to control all aspects of their kids lives.

Comment: I got a chuckle out of this article. We do feel very sorry for our American friends and relatives. Indeed, many of them are quite distraught. They are well past embarrassment.

He is honest and open with all Canadians, and not afraid in the least to discuss his failings with disappointed Canadians from anywhere, about anything, and regardless of ideology.

We are lucky, and I'm very proud to have Justin as my Prime Minister!

Comment: I bought my '62 TR3B from Calumet Auto Wreckers for $175 in 1968.  I drove it from Chicago to Ft. Jackson South Carolina in 1970.  When I got orders for Vietnam I was going to sell it for a few hundred $$. Then I remembered hearing my father and uncles talking about their old cars and how much they wished they still had them.  

So I drove it back to Chicago, put it under a tarp and was fortunate enough to come home to it.  It's sitting in my garage for a clutch replacement right now. Every Spring, when it's time to bring it back to life, it still smells of worn leather seats, dust, rust and leaking oil.  It makes me feel 20 years old all over again for a few minutes.

Comment: The period of agrarian expansion in the western Canadian frontier saw numerous "populist" groups arise. These were mainly borne out of agrarian and labour unrest. Most were disappointed by the governments' (provincial and federal) apathy towards the farmer or the labourer. These people's actions led to the development of populist parties like the Cooperative Commonwealth Confederation which was most famously led by Saint Tommy Clement Douglas during peak popularity, and which eventually gave birth to great things like free health care. And they were indubitably populists.

Absolutely nothing wrong with "populism." Enjoying free healthcare? Thank Canadian populists like Tommy Douglas and early labour organizations.

Fake news is almost exclusively from satire sites who publish false info on purpose which readers either don't realize or which get picked up by other outlets who drop the clarification that it's satire - sometimes b/c they didn't even realize it. Comment: Once you understand how the Canadian stumpage system works, it's hard not to see it as a government subsidy to the industry and workers.  Rather than auction off timber rights, under stumpage the government collects fees based on the lumber companies' difference between production cost and selling price.
Under an auction-based system (used in the USA), the lumber companies bear the risk of price fluctuations.  If prices drop due to excess supply, they are incented to reduce production.  However under stumpage, the Canadian producers have no incentive to reduce production, and their profit levels are assured, because if the lumber prices drop, the stumpage cost drops so they remain whole.  It is an insurance scheme for industry profits - they have transferred the risk to tax payers.  The gov collects less revenue from selling its wood, but what do they care so long as lumber companies and unions are happy?  No wonder USA is upset, their government won't reduce fees when prices drop.

Comment: Trump also made promises he simply cannot keep. Automation has removed far more manufacturing jobs than offshoring has. Even if companies were forced to bring their plants back to the US (something that's not going to happen), these would not be the skilled labor jobs of two generations ago and they wouldn't pay significantly better than Walmart. Technology prohibits this approach to economic revival unless we go full-scale controlled economy with manufacturing, and history clearly shows that controlled economies only produce additional poverty. 

Then there's the promise to shred NAFTA and other trade agreements and kick out illegal aliens. The primary way this would impact all Americans would be in vastly increased grocery bills. Between imports and migrant labor, we enjoy some of the proportionally lowest grocery prices ever. And say goodbye to fresh produce in wintertime.

The Democrats ignored the white working class while Trump sold them false hopes. I'm unsure which was worse.

Comment: Those wars were all going on before Obama was President and Presidents before him could not stop them. The problem is that the wars cannot be ended militarily. Iraq and Afghanistan are examples-- after years of fighting, thousands of bombs and missiles, we took back land and defeated enemy fighters-- with a surge of 100,000 US troops in Afghanistan. We thought those wars were over. Except for leaving a total of less that 15,000 troops in those two countries, we withdrew. We are training Iraqi forces and they have become good fighters in Syria against ISIS-- but more US troops are needed. In Afghanistan after a surge in Obama's second term of 100,000 US plus another 40,000 Nato and US allied troops we defeated the Taliban, and supported a government. But the Taliban (with Russian assistance), Al Quaeda, and ISIS are on the rise and our small force is not enough to stop them. These wars do not end militarily-- aid, development, and local political leadership are needed.

Comment: The Klutina Road is an RS2477 trail, which means it is a public right of way. It doesn't belong to Ahtna. It belongs to all the people of Alaska. But it is useless if all you can do is drive to the end of the road and spread out along the river bank below the ordinary high-water mark.

Typical of Ahtna, these folks want to demand that the rest of the state support them through usery fees. They extracted hundreds of dollars from my family for the use of the Chitina fishery for more than a decade before a survey showed that they didn't own the land they were trying to control. But they keep trying.

This RS2477 trail existed before the ANILCA and, again, Ahtna made their selections trying to tie up the land so nobody but them could use the land, even the parts that belonged to the state or feds.

No, I don't buy the "oh poor people, give them some money" mentality. Go out and get jobs like the rest of us. You don't own the right of way. Stop pretending you do.

Comment: Obama didn't ban people from coming to this country from Syria.  He signed a law stating that people who had recently travelled to these countries and were generally eligible to travel to the US on a visa waiver couldn't do so if they recently travelled to Syria.  Let's suppose that I am a French aid worker in Iraq and I wish to travel to a conference in the US about the plight of Yazidi women.  Obama's law would mean that I couldn't use my French passport to travel to the US on a visa waiver, but that doesn't mean that I'd be completely barred from travelling to the US.  I would need to visit the US embassy in Paris and get approval from the officials there, who are trained to evaluate people who wish to visit the US.  Since I had a legitimate reason for being in Iraq as an aid worker, I would likely still be approved to travel to the conference.  Nobody is being arbitrarily banned from going to the US under the Obama rule; there was just additional scrutiny.

Comment: This is a beautiful site that many folks will enjoy, kudos to the State Park for prioritizing aesthetics and design in the development. However, while it's true that the completed section of Curry Ridge Trail climbs to a point where "you can walk the tundra to beautiful Lake 1787", this should have been followed with a caveat: PLEASE use low impact travel protocols on the fragile tundra until further access trails are built. Spread out, don't travel single file, use rock and exposed gravel wherever possible, avoid wet spots. This is some of the most pristine alpine tundra I've seen so close to the road system, and it's going to get hammered if people aren't conscious about travel. I hope we can love the area enough to keep some of its wild beauty intact.

Comment: I've jumped a number of stranger's cars over the years who've waved jumper cables at me in a parking lot.  I always pull up alongside them, roll down my window, and then with my meanest face and deepest menacing voice, I say "Hey Buddy, you trying to start something?".  Always gets a laugh after a few seconds.  I carry a very long, very heavy duty set of booster cables in my truck.  I never use the pieces of junk that people buy from CTire.  I also have a connector under my hood that I use to connect my removable winch and I connect the booster cables to the connector.  First connect the Red (+) on the connector or battery to the Red (+) post on the dead vehicle's battery unless they have a separate red lug for boosting.  Then connect the charging Black (-) to a solid ground point on the dead car or if you can't find one, connect to the negative or Black post.  By connecting the Black (-) last to a separate ground point greatly reduces the danger of explosion in the event of a spark.

Comment: You may well be right. Time constraints could severely alter the mathematics (and I'm not even sure that tidal power *would* be more economical - just thought it might be). 

Ironically - desalination as a technology has had almost no major advancements in decades, nobody ever really bothered since it was always too expensive. It's not any cheaper now though -it's just that water demand has kept growing and water supply has not been able to keep up. A technology that had always been too expensive to bother with is suddenly economical because of the increase in scarcity. This isn't just true in Cape Town either - it's a global phenomenon. The combination of population growth, pollution and climate change is making water an ever more scarce resource thus making previously unviable technologies like desalination worthwhile for the first time.

Comment: Agree, but the work they do is usually part of their education/thesis. While they get little, they get an education and usually TA-ships and salary are more than enough to cover tuition and living expenses. 
The problem is that grad students are used as cheap research staff, which isn't right. Hiring research staff and trained technicians is quite expensive and so grad students often take up those duties and do science for little money. If you're running a lab, it is easier and much cheaper to have grad students "running" the show, instead of hiring a technician or staff scientist. Not to mention the requirement of grad training to score funding. Nobody cares that there are hardly any post-grad jobs in academia, and with faculty status so fiercely protected by unions and tenure, there is no way to get rid of underperforming faculty - which is ironic where there is so much supply of fresh, motivated and aspiring academics from grad school.

Comment: Don't touch the PFD.

Do cut more.

Kill the tax credits.

Implement a flat ~10% income tax.

Implement a stiff seasonal sales tax.  Exclude necessities that residents rely on such as unprepared food, medicine, utilities, etc.  Tourists would finally pay their share.

While the flat income tax is more regressive than a graduated tax, it also would be more politically acceptable.  Everyone would pay the same percentage.  Everyone would pay something (the PFD check would be taxable income).  The rich would pay more.  It's relatively simple and straight-forward to implement.  Out of state workers would finally pay their share.

Imposing taxes would wake up voters.  As long as free money magically appears and pays for all of our government services, it's easy to just go fishing and trust someone else to run things. That's how we end up with Taj Mahawkers.  Our legislators feel no accountability to us.  Once government funding comes out of our wallets, we pay attention.  And vote.

Comment: I am dismayed by the "dead money" defense. Money goes where the best return is. It is true that corporations need working capital. It seems that he government wishes to regulate this. It is said that  income splitting only affects 1 in 500 businesses and is estimated to increase tax revenue by $250 M. The extra administration that this measure cause is likely to offset the meager gains from imposing this measure.  This is not what the fight is about. Think $28 B in "passive" investment income. Corporations that have only passive investment income are deemed to be fairly treated by the tax system and will see no change. Reinvested passive income is also fairly treated using the same logic. The passive income proposals are effectively aimed at clawing back a portion of the small business tax deduction in situations where the business owner has retained earnings that are deemed excessive. This is not "dead money". Tax it now and get  less tax later. Not well thought out!

Comment: Since the author didn't really bother to answer the question seriously, I'll take a stab at it. 

Legally, if you smoke marijuana in your yard and it wafts into your neighbour's yard, that's a "nuisance" in the legal sense. Is it actionable as such? Possibly. If it interferes with your neighbour's reasonable enjoyment of his property, then yes he could sue you over it.

More practically, I think this is going to have to be handled by municipalities the way that other common nuisances are handled - through bylaws. As it stands many municipalities have already outlawed through bylaw open air burning. In Toronto, for instance, you can't have a fire pit in  your backyard, although cooking appliances are exempted.

As I see it, similar rules could come into force if marijuana use becomes a serious nuisance.

An overwhelming consensus of evidenced-based climate science, and the conclusions of an overwhelming consensus of climatologists, validates the Anthropogenic Global Warming (AGW) hypothesis.

Comment: All of those are good ideas. One of the problems is that our local district attorney's office has steadfastly refused to prosecute drug dealers for years. They cite a lack of resources, but I suspect that if those dealers were ruining the DA's neighborhood those resources would be found before the end of the day.

As to the other ideas, Yolo County, near Sacramento, conducted a large trial of them. They took 63 people off the river, carefully assessed their needs, got them drug treatment and job training while housing them in a hotel, provided veterinary service to their pets, assisted them with outstanding legal problems and interfaced with the feds to help them get whatever benefits they qualified for. In the end, just over half of them successfully re-entered society. Yeah, we could/should do that here, imo.

Comment: After 12 years away from Eugene, working and traveling in different sections of the world, I never had one thing stolen... including five years in the Middle East, and seven years RVing in the USA and Canada.  After two weeks in our new apartment at North Green Apts, where security is dismal or perhaps the norm, our precious two recumbent bikes, 18 years old, were stolen from an outside bike rack  where they were secured by two U-Locks plus cables that were cut.  The bikes were gone, the U-locks never opened, as the thieves obviously just took the bikes apart.  We reported the theft to police.  With a yawn, they took down the details, one of many in this crime ridden town.  Obviously, bike theft in Eugene is not high on their agenda.

Part of the blame, in my opinion, rests on the shoulders of the police department. Their lack of creative sting operations leaves me in a quandary.  As a minimum, it's time to establish a city wide, volunteer group to carry out what the police fail to do.

Comment: Ra.  

Ra (/rɑː/;[1] Egyptian: Rꜥ, Rˤ) or Re (/reɪ/; Coptic: ⲣⲏ, Rē) is the ancient Egyptian sun god. By the Fifth Dynasty in the 25th and 24th centuries BC, he had become a major god in ancient Egyptian religion, identified primarily with the noon sun.

All forms of life were believed to have been created by Ra, who called each of them into existence by speaking their secret names. Alternatively man was created from Ra's tears and sweat, hence the Egyptians call themselves the "Cattle of Ra." In the myth of the Celestial Cow it is recounted how mankind plotted against Ra and how he sent his eye as the goddess Sekhmet to punish them. When she became bloodthirsty she was pacified by drinking beer mixed with red dye.

Works for me!

Bring on the beer!

27 centuries--must be the truth!

Comment: The problem with articles like this is that many people jump to the conclusion that anybody owning one of these homes is rich and needs to have a big time slap upside the head.   While that maybe the case with some it is not with a lot of us.    I bought my place in the early 70s as that was all I could afford in South Surrey.   Because of my income I had to commute to even keep this house.   Things grew up around us and we worked hard to maintain the house and property.   Now they are telling us it is worth about $2 or slightly less.  We are retired on a pension and watch our taxes climb each year.   We do not want to sell it is our HOME.  Where would we go?  Everything we know is here, friends, social network, hospital, Drs. etc. etc.    There are lots of us on this street in the same boat.   I guess in time they will force us out and we will have to go to some rabbit warren and put up with all the crap that goes with it but please don't think we are rich because a lot of us are not.

Comment: September 5th is the fiscal year deadline for cities to apply for the Byrne Justice Assistance Grants. Denver's allotment for 2014 was $404,307.  According to a lawsuit filed by the city of Chicago; the Justice department in July added two new requirements to be eligible for these grant funds; 1.) To detain persons at ICE request for 48hrs and 2.)Give ICE access to city facilities to interrogate any suspected non-citizen held there. These requirements seem very reasonable and I can think of no reason to object to these requirements other than to protect non-citizens that are in the country illegally. Yet they still want the $400,000 plus grant money. That is an oxymoron. I would rather have the Justice Department award more funding to other cities in Colorado that do comply with the new requirements in an effort to rid our country of illegal immigrants. And let me state that I would welcome everyone of them back in once they have gone through the immigration process.

Comment: Alaska only needs to build 30 miles of steel pipeline to pass gas from Nslope to markets..  This section could be handled easily with flexpipe, but there's a bunch of Alaskan kids who went to welding school so they could get a job welding on a big pipeline.

https://goo.gl/maps/UizVqPo4Wux

Multiple parallel of divergent/convergent flexpipe gaslines can be plowed 7' deep with tile plows, quick and efficient...
youtube:  wolfe tile plow

Flexpipe can be built bulletproof too..
goog:  bulletproof graphene plastic  [AK has 300million tons of graphite/graphene]

Gasline architecture of multiple flexpipes in a network will prevent 100% gasflow shutdown, a single pipe is a fools target and a National Security Risk.

Flexpipe can be pinched off with a portable hydraulic tool, run with a powerpack or hyd-lines plugged into a dozer or excavator.

Flexpipe hauls gas with much less investment and operational cost, and has near zero footprint in wilderness. 100% of Nslope gas can be flexpiped.

Comment: Pt. 2
By 1965, there was a decisive shift in Catholic attitudes and presence in the struggle for racial justice.  In response to Martin Luther King, Jr.'s summons for the nation's religious leaders to come to Selma, Alabama, the response from white priests and sisters was "enormous".  Despite the opposition from the Local Bishops, "priests from fifty different dioceses, sisters and laity flocked to Alabama."

But for the most part, American bishops were passive and tepid in their responses then and sadly, now.
--------------------------------------
Cyprian Davis, THE HISTORY OF BLACK CATHOLICS IN THE UNITED STATES [New York: Crossroads, 1990]
John T. McGreevy, PARISH BOUNDARIES: THE CATHOLIC ENCOUNTER WITH RACE IN THE TWENTIETH-CENTURY URBAN NORTH [Chicago: University of Chicago Press, 1996]
Charles Marsh GOD'S LONG SUMMER: STORIES OF FAITH AND CIVIL RIGHTS [Princeton, NJ: Princeton University Press, 2008]

Comment: On the topic of rental supply, please consider this. We want more supply. We want to encourage it, not discourage it. Then consider, among the huge, *already-existing* pre-1991 housing stock (in Toronto and elsewhere), the many owners who would like to earn income by letting self-contained units in their houses, or even a second house. Were it possible for them to do so easily, there would be NO ten-year wait for renters to occupy these already-existing spaces. They could be on the market almost immediately. Why aren't they? Look no further than the oppressive rent controls that prevent potential landlords from becoming actual landlords. For one thing, they can't raise their rents by more than the cost of living without cutting through miles of red tape. For another, prohibitions against ending a lease for any but the extremest of reasons makes them quake in their boots.  

If rent controls on ALL properties, both post- AND pre-1991, were abolished, the shortage of supply would vanish.

Comment: "Students would learn more outside the classroom if exposed to young people from a greater variety of backgrounds than they’d typically find at a top-tier college."
I had a roommate from Westchester NY and one from inner city Baltimore.  I grew up on a farm in Colorado.  The only thing we had in common was that we all got into the same top-tier college.
The author is erroneously equating academic capability with diversity. 

BTW - I guarantee that if you had a dorm with 1/2 elite college students and 1/2 vocational students they would separate themselves with maybe two in a hundred that would actually "cohort" with the other group.  People separate themselves and group according to similarities, always have.

Comment: Last month when the area where I purchased my home finally got about 10 inches of snow, there was a knock at the door. I opened it and there was a young Alaska Native teenager with a shovel in hand. "Shovel your yard for $5.oo." I said okay. When he was done I gave him $10 and went next door and later saw him further down the street.  My grand kids like to play their video games but my daughter says, "Finish your chores, first." If they don't do their chores, they get some money deducted from their weekly allowance. After the first deduction they hardly ever miss.

Comment: I'll be voting for the next CPC leader and only four names will appear on my ballot - Chong, O'Toole, Bernier, and Raitt - probably in that order.  Those are the only four individuals I would want leading the CPC.  

What I'm looking for in a leader are: 1) values that align with my own, and well-articulated and formulated policy which I believe will help Canadians; 2) the ability to broaden the C/conservative tent on a national level; 3) the ability to compete in a federal election (i.e., across all regions of the country); and 4) the ability to lead an effective opposition if defeated in 2019 and, when the time comes, lead a government.   

The remaining candidates don't pass all four of those tests, in my opinion.

Comment: Caffeine is a drug like any other, and the gist of the article is true -- if you are a confirmed addict, you need it to be "normal".

But it is fairly benign as drugs go, and moderate use can be quite helpful.  A couple of cups in the morning can get you going a helluvalot faster, making better use of a time that is almost always frantic if you are juggling kids and a demanding job.

If you are sucking back double  lattés and Red Bull throughout the day, sure, the benefits will be quickly outweighed by the disadvantages.  But a nice jolt of kickapoo joy juice in the AM and abstinence after, say 10 AM, will  maximize the benefit and minimize the downside.

Besides......a good cuppa joe is darned tasty!
